heading: 1 Workshop 1: Data Handling Skills
text: Aims:Practice importing .csv data file RStudio using read_csv()Practice importing .csv data file RStudio using read_csv()Practice inspecting data RStudio.Practice inspecting data RStudio.Use different data wrangling functions develop data handling skills.Use different data wrangling functions develop data handling skills.Check basic summary statistics.Check basic summary statistics.

heading: 1.1 Exercise 1: Import the Data
text: Import Data File guess_who.csvBefore begin, need tidyverse package loaded.Next import data file store object called dataset.see error saying find function read_csv() usually means loaded (installed) tidyverse package.
code:
install.packages("tidyverse") #install tidyverse if you do not have it.
library(tidyverse) #loads tidyverse.
dataset <- read_csv("guess_who.csv")

heading: 1.2 Exercise 2: Inspect and Check Your Data
text: Take look newly imported data fileCheck top right panel (environment) also use code inspect data set.really important look variable names ’ll using code later .Answer Question 2.1 - 2.2 worksheet.
code:
view(dataset) # this will open the data in a new tab.
names(dataset) # this will show the variable names.

heading: 1.3 Exercise 3: Change a Variable Name
text: One variable names quite long. can annoying keep typing outChange variable name do_you_own_a_pet pet. rename() function let rename variable.Check worked:
code:
dataset <- dataset %>%
  rename(pet = do_you_own_a_pet)
names(dataset) # ask for the variable names again

heading: 1.4 Exercise 4: Remove a Variable
text: really care age variable next exercises.Let’s remove .code create new object (start removing things, best keep original data file called dataset environment)code :Create new object called mydata.Create new object called mydata.Take original data called datasetTake original data called dataset“” %>%“” %>%Use select() function remove age placing minus symbol - front .Use select() function remove age placing minus symbol - front .now , use object called mydata original data set.
code:
mydata <- dataset %>%
  select(-age)

heading: 1.5 Exercise 5: Filter Cases
text: can select particular cases data setFor example, ask: many people city Birmingham using code :Check console (bottom left panel) answer.code :Take mydata …Take mydata …Filter city variable.Filter city variable.use double equals symbol == specify exact match.use double equals symbol == specify exact match.’ve added “birmingham” speech marks. Note lowercase match data set …’ve added “birmingham” speech marks. Note lowercase match data set …count() number data points.count() number data points.Adapt code answer question 5.1 worksheet.
code:
mydata %>%
  filter(city == "birmingham") %>%
  count()

heading: 1.6 Exercise 6: Guess Who?
text: can filter based multiple criteria.code show us someone Brighton, dog, drink coffee.can also use less /symbols filter data, example, show people art enjoyment score less 20:Use learned adapt code play GUESS ? complete questions 6.1-6.2 worksheet.
code:
mydata %>%
  filter(city == "brighton", pet == "dog", coffee == 0)
mydata %>%
  filter(maths < 20)

heading: 1.7 Exercise 7: Create a New Variable
text: Sometimes might want compute new scores variablesAdd three enjoyment scores maths, science, art create overall score called total_score.code :Take mydata overwrite (ready add new variable) …Take mydata overwrite (ready add new variable) …Use mutate() function create new variable named total_score equal = maths + science + art.Use mutate() function create new variable named total_score equal = maths + science + art.View data set look new column see worked.Now, can look highest lowest total enjoyment score.slice_min find row lowest score:slice_max find row highest score:Answer questions 7.1-7.2 worksheet.
code:
mydata <- mydata %>%
  mutate(total_score = maths + science + art)
view(mydata)
mydata %>%
  slice_min(total_score)
mydata %>%
  slice_max(total_score)

heading: 1.8 Exercise 8: Counting and Removing Missing Data
text: Real data sets often missing data pointsDifferent people differing views treat missing data points. today, just identify remove . view data, might notice blanks degree everyone studying one.code :Calculate total number using sum() …Calculate total number using sum() …missing data points (R calls .na)missing data points (R calls .na)can direct particular column using mydata$degree. essentially means “look mydata column called degree. use dollar sign $ specify column.can direct particular column using mydata$degree. essentially means “look mydata column called degree. use dollar sign $ specify column.want remove , can use filter() !Note: overwrite mydata remove cases.Answer question 8.1 worksheet.
code:
sum(is.na(mydata$degree))
mydata <- mydata %>% 
  filter(!is.na(degree))

heading: 1.9 Exercise 9: Summary Statistics
text: might want know average enjoyment score?can use code look across data set whole:Look output console (bottom left panel) answer questions 9.1-9.3 worksheet.Well Done. reached end workshop. Give extra challenge try optional exercise worksheet.
code: summary(mydata)

heading: 2 Workshop 2: Summarising and Describing Data
text: Aims:Practice importing .csv data file RStudio using read_csv()Practice importing .csv data file RStudio using read_csv()Practice inspecting data RStudio.Practice inspecting data RStudio.Calculate mean standard deviation using group_by() summarise() functions.Calculate mean standard deviation using group_by() summarise() functions.Visually inspect data using plots describe data distributions.Visually inspect data using plots describe data distributions.

heading: 2.1 Exercise 1: Import the Data
text: Import Data File: sleep.csvBefore begin, need tidyverse package loaded.Next import data file store object called dataset.see error saying find function read_csv() usually means loaded (installed) tidyverse package.
code:
install.packages("tidyverse") #install tidyverse if you do not have it.
library(tidyverse) #loads tidyverse.
dataset <- read_csv("sleep.csv")

heading: 2.2 Exercise 2: Inspect and Check Your Data
text: Take look newly imported data fileCheck top right panel (environment) also use code inspect data set.really important look variable names ’ll using code later .
code:
view(dataset) # this will open the data in a new tab.
names(dataset) # this will show the variable names.

heading: 2.3 Exercise 3: Calculate the Total Sleep Score
text: Sometimes might want compute new scores variablesAdd two sleep scores sleep_quality drowsy scores create overall score called total_sleep.code :Create object called mydata using original dataset …Create object called mydata using original dataset …Use mutate() function create new variable named total_sleep equal = scale_1 + scale_2.Use mutate() function create new variable named total_sleep equal = scale_1 + scale_2.View data set look new column see worked.Answer questions 3.1-3.2 worksheet.
code:
mydata <- dataset %>%
  mutate(total_sleep = scale_1 + scale_2)
view(mydata)

heading: 2.4 Exercise 4: Calculate Descriptive Statistics
text: Just shown lecture, use code calculate mean standard deviation total_sleep. Remember, want use total score calculated exercise 3, use two subscales.need change NULL match data set. Try give go first, aren’t sure look help.Think :name variable split data file (e.g., grouping variable/independent variable called data set)name variable split data file (e.g., grouping variable/independent variable called data set)name score want find mean standard deviation (e.g., dependent variable called data set)name score want find mean standard deviation (e.g., dependent variable called data set)look environment (top right panel) see new object called desc. descriptive statistics stored. called desc can call anything like. best keep object names short informative. can now view object using view() function.Answer questions 4.1-4.2 worksheet.
code:
desc <-  mydata %>%
  group_by(NULL) %>%
  summarise(m_sleep = mean(NULL),
            sd_sleep = sd(NULL))
desc <-  mydata %>%
  group_by(energy_drink) %>%
  summarise(m_sleep = mean(total_sleep),
            sd_sleep = sd(total_sleep))
view(desc)

heading: 2.5 Exercise 5: Explore Data with Plots
text: Generate box plot:Generate histograms:Generate density plots:Answer questions 5.1-5.2 worksheet.
code:
ggplot(mydata, aes(x = energy_drink, y = total_sleep)) +
  geom_boxplot(width = .4)
ggplot(mydata, aes(x = total_sleep, fill = energy_drink)) +
  geom_histogram(colour = "black") +
  facet_wrap(~ energy_drink)
ggplot(mydata, aes(x = total_sleep, fill = energy_drink)) +
  geom_density(alpha = .5) +
  facet_wrap(~ energy_drink)

heading: 2.6 Exercise 6: What Does facet_wrap() do?
text: Re-run density plot code, except time delete final line. show facet_wrap() . notice plot now?Use code without facet_wrap().
code:
ggplot(mydata, aes(x = total_sleep, fill = energy_drink)) +
  geom_density(alpha = .5)

heading: 2.7 Answer question 6.1 on the worksheet.
text: Well Done. reached end workshop.

heading: 3 Workshop 3: t-Tests
text: Aims:Practice running interpreting two-sample t-test RStudio.Practice running interpreting two-sample t-test RStudio.Practice running interpreting paired t-test RStudio.Practice running interpreting paired t-test RStudio.

heading: 3.1 Part One
text: Part one today’s workshop involved running two-sample t-test, appropriate independent measures design two groups.use data file last week, aiming answer “impact energy drink consumption () sleep quality?”

heading: 3.2 Exercise 1: Import the Data
text: Import Data File: sleep.csvBefore begin, need tidyverse package loaded.import data file. Make sure total_sleep score calculated last week.
code:
install.packages("tidyverse") #install if needed.
install.packages("rstatix")   #install if needed.
library(tidyverse)            #load package
library(rstatix)              #load package
mydata <- read_csv("sleep.csv")

heading: 3.3 Exercise 2: Inspect and Check Your Data
text: Take look newly imported data fileCheck top right panel (environment) also use code inspect data set.really important look variable names ’ll using code later .
code:
view(mydata) # this will open the data in a new tab.
names(mydata) # this will show the variable names.

heading: 3.4.1 Check Heteroscedasticity with Levene’s Test
text: Use Levene’s test check homogeneity variance.Change DV name dependent variable.Change IV name independent (grouping) variable.Change DATA name data.Run code interpret output:p-value significant (<.05) variances differ across two groups assumption violated, issue. p-value significant (>.05) variances roughly equal.Write follows:F(df) = XX.XX, p = .XXXEnter degrees freedom place df, F value, p-value. Remember use p <.001 p-value smaller 0.001.example degrees freedom 36, F 3.25, p .065:F(36) = 3.25, p = .065
code: leveneTest(DV ~ IV, data = DATA)

heading: 3.4.2 Check Normality with Shapiro-Wilk Test and Histograms
text: need check normality groups separately. can filter groups:use dollar sign $ point R particular column. example, using shapiro.test(yes$total_sleep) saying run Shapiro Test yes data set column called total_scoreAgain, want p-values significant. non-significant p-value means data roughly normally distributed. p-value significant, issue indicates data normally distributed.reporting Shapiro-Wilk test, just need report test statistics (w = XX) p-value. example look like:W = 0.98, p = .875You can also visually check data quick histogram:Check plots panel, use blue arrow switch two plots.
code:
#first create a data set that contains energy drink consumers only.
yes <- mydata %>%
  filter(energy_drink == "yes")

#then run the test
shapiro.test(yes$total_sleep)

#then create a data set that contains non-consumers only.
no <- mydata %>%
  filter(energy_drink == "no")

#then run the test
shapiro.test(no$total_sleep)
hist(yes$total_sleep)
hist(no$total_sleep)

heading: 3.4.3 A Note on Assumptions
text: Assessing assumptions can little tricky. two-sample t-test run something called Welch’s t-test can cope violations assumptions.might ask point checking . One reason helpful report characteristics (heteroscedasticity normality) data.

heading: 3.5 Exercise 4: Run the Two-Sample t-Test and ask for Cohen’s d
text: Run t-test.Ask Cohen’s d:Interpret t-test. - significant? - effect size? - significant, groups differ?final question, need descriptive statistics. Hint: use code last week find mean standard deviation two groups.
code:
t.test(total_sleep ~ energy_drink, data = mydata, var.equal = FALSE, alternative = "two.sided")
cohens_d(data = mydata, total_sleep ~ energy_drink, var.equal = FALSE)

heading: 3.6 Part Two
text: Part two today’s workshop involved running paired t-test, appropriate repeated measures design two conditions.sleep intervention study. group participants completed sleep quality questionnaire completing intervention aimed improve sleep. Afterwards, participants completed sleep questionnaire .independent variable time point: , . dependent variable sleep quality score (0-100).

heading: 3.7 Exercise 5: Import the Data
text: calle object int (short intervention data)
code: int <- read_csv("sleep_intervention.csv")

heading: 3.8 Exercise 6: Inspect and Check Your Data
text: Take look newly imported data fileCheck top right panel (environment) also use code inspect data set.
code:
view(int) # this will open the data in a new tab.
names(int) # this will show the variable names.

heading: 3.9 Exercise 7: Check Assumptions
text: time check normality, heteroscedasiticty apply repeated measures designs. However, need ensure difference score normally distributed.interpret report way earlier (exercise 3).
code:
diff <- int$post - int$pre  #this will calculate the difference score.
shapiro.test(diff)          # run the Shapiro test
hist(diff)                  # also visually inspect data

heading: 3.10 Exercise 8: Run the Paired t-Test and ask for Cohen’s d
text: paired t-test little different compared two-sample t-test.Change NULL1 column first condition.Change NULL1 column first condition.Change NULL2 column second condition.Change NULL2 column second condition.(Hint: need use dollar sign $ specify column)Annoyingly, need use different package Cohen’s d paired t-test.
code:
t.test(NULL1, NULL2, paired = TRUE)
t.test(int$before, int$after, paired = TRUE)
install.package("effectsize") #install if needed.
library(effectsize)
effectsize::cohens_d(int$before, int$after, paired = TRUE)

heading: 3.11 Exercise 9: Calculate Descriptive Statistics
text: good news paired sample t-test, can use summary() function obtain descriptive statistics.Make note mean standard deviation conditions.Well Done. reached end workshop.
code: summary(int)
